reviewText:
Samurai Warriors, or Sengoku Musou as it's known in Japan is an established series of 'hack and slash' games by Koei which are based in the Sengoku era of Japan. If you've ever played a Dynasty Warriors game you know what to expect as the two are almost identical with the exception of the cast and the locations (DW is in China, SW is Japan). Both are by Koei Tecmo and seem to use very similar engines.

The game recreates a turbulent period of history in Japan now known as the Warring States period. Battles raged all over Japan to try and unify the land and Samurai Warriors 4-II lets you take part in many of the decisive battles, using many different factions.  Each mission has a primary objective (usually defeat an enemy commander or reach an escape point) with several other objectives that can happen during the mission. It can be frantic at times, especially when multiple objectives appear within a short space of time and some of them are timed meaning you have to act fast.

The maps are laid out well but do get a little repetitive (as many of the battles were fought in the same locations). Each character has a variety of different attacks effective against different kinds of enemies, as well as having a 'Rage' system (which makes you do more damage for a short period of time) and a character specific 'Musou' attack, which is effectively a super and should be very familiar to anyone who has played Dynasty Warriors.

The game is split into a few different modes: Story Mode (clear a few missions with specific characters as their story unfolds), Free Mode (use any character on any unlocked mission), Survival Mode (ascend an endless tower that gets progressively harder) and it also has a Dojo where you can do several things like create custom characters, listen to music tracks or even read the biographies of the real-life Sengoku era warriors. The only criticism I have of Story Mode is that only a handful of characters have a story mode that involves them to any real extent so some people might be disappointed that their favourite character isn't represented much.

There is also two-player functionality, both local and co-op online. I've tested the online with a friend on the other side of the world with both of us taking turns to host and it's been flawless. No connection issues and no noticable lag whatsoever. Brilliant fun to play with a friend online; I can't comment on the split-screen as I haven't tried it.

Ultimately the game has a very simple premise; kill hundreds (or thousands) of generic grunt enemies, bring down every warlord, daimyo or rebellion you come across and try to unify Japan under your banner, whoever's that may be. As mindless as it can be sometimes, it's still a very fun game and some missions do require you to do more than just mow everything down.

I definitely recommend the game itself; the DLC however is ridiculously expensive for what it is. Unless you're desperate to see the female cast in nurse outfits, swimsuits and the like, wait until a sale to pick the DLC up. The game itself is still worth the purchase.

Bought it because I've played Samurai Warriors 2 and loved every single character that was in the game. Since I don't own a Wii/PS3/PS4 this is my only option to play the latest installment. It attracted me since we can now change the weapon into something you really want, much easier than it was in Samurai Warriors 2. Which means I can optimised the characters I enjoy using to the fullest.

Storyline: 4/10
Every installment of Samurai Warriors, new characters are added and developed on the storyline. Being a 10th anniversary game, I hope that they added story mode for all characters. Didn't really bother me even if the older characters had PS2 graphics for their scenarios as I viewed it as a collector's item being the 1st Samurai Warriors game on PC. But they didn't. Story wise, I've predicted it weak as the characters featured didn't really play a major role in Sengoku era. I could accept that.

Characters: 5/10
What I couldn't accept is how the new character personality turn out. Head of the Il clan, apologising to every living creature on the planet in every sentence of her dialogue? Descendant of the Uesugi speaking one liners while Kanetsugu does all the talking? An Afro hair girl in netty outfit fighting with a piece of cloth? A be-spectacled guy fighting using a shield emitting laser beams? If you could accept all that, then buy the game or like me avoid using them. KT is clearly running out of personalities to create for Samurais especially with close to 60 in the roster.
Thankfully KT have been kind to still place the older characters in, which are my favourite since Samurai Warriors 2 with superior movesets making the gameplay fun.

Difficulty: 7/10
The game has 4 difficulty mode, Easy to Nightmare. Hard is like normal in previous games, while nightmare mode is a huge jump in difficulty. Unless you are using Hisahide with the only infinite combo in the game, I don't see how you can attempt nightmare mode at the start.

Combat: 11/10 (means it exceeded my expectation)
The combat is a major improvement, loads of new moves, attacks chain better, hyper attacks to reduce monotony of killing 1000 soldiers. Instead of spamming same attacks there is now a counter/parry system to retaliate by pressing button shown on screen. Some of the new features are overpowered- a single move killing 5 generals at the cost of spirit gauge and 1 musou gauge.

Controls: 8/10
The horse control went down the drain, as calling it usually ends up with a horse running in zigzag refusing to pick you up unless you stand still or beside corners of a wall.

BGM: 7/10
Fits the theme. However not my liking. The best BGM from Warriors game is in One Piece Pirate Warriors.

Online play: 6/10
The co-op is not stable at the moment this review is written, I could play with someone far from Asia but it crashes when I play with someone in Asia. Weird indeed.

Most of the game hours I have was either from falling asleep due to hectic schedule or testing game mechanics for writting guides. I don't aim to 100% everything for the reason of new abyssmal characters. I do know it will take close to a 100hrs to collect most of the weapons and max every character to optimum. I am 3/4 thru, left the characters I loath using and perhaps time to put an end to the game.

Overall it is a fun experience, a definite improvement in combat/ loot customization. Even though some say it looks like PS2 graphic, I still love it because it looks like a PS3 port to me. The DLC isn't worth collecting, not my type of weapons, the mounts aren't the strongest and the stages are just reskinned, inverted images of the storyline stages with no cutscene or dialogue. They are finally working harder to make their games gain more reception by targetting a different group of gamers.

I would give it 7/10 overall. I don't rate a game by graphics since it is acceptable and low in my priority. Quite sick of nice looking games with boring gameplay like alot of recent HD console games Squeenix is making.

reviewText:
I prefer Samurai Warriors on PS2. Compared with other Warrior's titles today, SW4-II feels really dated. Most of the moves are imported from SW1 and despite some great innovations made for DW8's combat system, they weren't carried over.

SW1 felt really immersive. Especially for me; for the most part it understood it was a period-piece and it was easy for a Japanese history-buff to feel like they were participating in the battles of the Sengoku Jidai. SW4-II feels more like an anime. The character designs are flamboyant, awkward and uninspired. The music, however, is really good and I've enjoyed this game's soundtrack long before it was released outside Japan. That said, even the music feels watered down compared to SW1.

This port is plagued with quite a few technical issues. I'm sure everyone's experience will vary, but...

I had to run the game in windowed mode otherwise, the game would get jittery. There's tons of framerate issues, that I ironically fixed by setting all settings to high and turning of dynamic shadows (I think that's what it was called). The textures are taken from the PS3's versions and not the PS4's-- lame, but not exactly a deal breaker on its own. When I begin to add all these issues together, I'm shocked to see that this is the first time I'm not enjoying a Warriors game.

I've played thousands of hours between DW1-DW8 and SW1. Sadly, I don't want to add another single hour into SW4-II.

I actually still want to recommend this game. My issues (aside from the technical, which can be worked around) are mainly subjective and based on my tastes. However, because the port does feel sloppy, and I feel Koei didn't put much effort into this title (especially considering this is a remake) I won't.

This game is still pretty cool, but get it on sale. I paid $35 for it, but still think that's too expensive for this experience. I'd rate this game at $20 max. If you have a PS4, I'd also suggest buying that version over this.

What to say about the game? I love it, and it hate at the same time. I've been a cult follower of Tecmo Koei and W OMEGA FORCE and the Dynasty/Samurai Warriors franchises. Simply put, I love them. The pc ports have gotten better with every installment which is nice, and they do nicely here with the amount of graphics options you can change.

Problem is on better systems when you turn the options all the way up, you get this film grain and lens flare with some saturation problems during cutscenes which really show the edges of the ps3 textures on the ps4 body textures. When using a controller, the keyboard button maps still show up instead of the controllers layout. I use a plug and play Xbox 360 controller. But thats not my main complaint of the game.

The writing with the Dynasty Warriors games have gotten better with each installment, though nothing will ever be able to beat Dynasty Warriors 5 in terms of narrative quality. As for the Samurai Warriors franchise, I feel like the writing just keeps getting worse. Not to mention this game was supposed to be more about character stories, yet in each game faction story its only about 2-3 characters and everyone else is left out and given the minor character treatment. Battles that were big in the series were narrated through with no chance of playing them, and each faction only had 5 battles to fight.

Each faction story takes what it considers historically canon in one story and butchers it in the other, and most of the time it does it to try to illicite an emotional response from the player. There is no consistency across the game whatsoever and each faction starts at a different point in time which works and doesn't work at the same time. Some characters are introduced you can't even play once and they die, and the only way you can play them is through free mode which is crap. So don't give me this bullcrap about Warriors 4-ii being about character stories, its still very much about the factions. Maybe they should look back and view Dynasty Warriors 5 as an examble for character stories, because every character on that game had a story and it was well written. This felt like a drama more than a game and every chance they had, they wanted to try to make the player feel like crap... Which really isn't the issue, its the story itself. It could of been written a lot better.

I know I should be emailing Koie or Omega Force about this, because they don't view Steam reviews, just thought I would make this aware to yall the buyers that the story is not the best of the series, or even close. I feel like Samurai Warriors 4 and its ii counterpart are the worst writing of the warriors series, with Chronicles being the best.

That being said, I don't recommend this game, but nor do I discourage people from buying it.

reviewText: Since I'm nearly done with the game myself and by the end of all this, I'll have around a bit over 70 parts, here's my honest take on it.  Well since I've been a fan of the series since the PS2 days, there's a lot I can say about this game that they really improved upon.  For one, the character roster.  The roster I have to say has improved since 3 and good to see some new faces as well as similar in the previous games. I'll also add that they taken notes from Chronicles in the tag aspect since it really does help and it doesn't harm you in anyway but instead help you all the more.  You'd still have to keep your eyes on your health bar but that's a given.  The pathfinding is also a big help since Samurai Warriors is more objective based than goal based like in Dynasty Warriors.  In its own respect, Samurai Warriors 4-II gives more of a challenge since you're on the clock on the field and you'll need a partner to help cover these goals so you can survive the battle.  As for the story aspect,  I do like how the characters interact with each other more in-story than just by game itself.  The character development is in a word: beautiful. At the most I can say, it gives you a more understanding feel to the characters than in previous games where the event was more important than the characters. Now I know and from what I read from other reviews, yes it's a hack and slash and to those with a very small view to say it's repetative, the work that was put into the stages are gorgeous and the music is just stellar. Even if you might be repeating some stages, it's the point of view that's mainly important.  How he/she perceive the view of the situation and all, how it affects them..that's what make this installment different.  The skill tree reminds me of the one in FFX but simplied, and all you would need is strategy tomes to access these skills. Most being useful on the field to either bolster your attack and defense, heal or net you more experience along with bettering your innate skills, I also need to add that when you hit 1000 KOs, you do get a bit of a super effect which says a lot more than being just the strongest in the land.  I think my only gripe is how come there wasn't a stand alone story for your created characters,  I feel they shouldn't be limited to just Survival and Free mode alone, I mean it could've been done like in Chronicles where your characters are given a choice on what they think and thereby going by relationship towards their peer or ruler depending on their way of life.  It's a longshot saying this, but I hope SW4 Empires comes to Steam and like with Dynasty Warriors Empires change up on how unification be done in a more simplified tone. As a whole, would I recommend getting this game for yourself?  I'd say if you can look past it being a hack and slash and being moderately challenging for a Warriors game, then yes go for it.  Try it for yourself and I think you'll find it that it's worth getting for your library.

TL;DR: It has it's issues. Get it on sale.

It's hard to judge this game on it's own, so I'll have to compare it to the candlestick that is Dynasty Warriors 8 on steam.

In comparison to Dynasty Warriors 8, this game falls short. There are only three game mode available: Story Mode, Free mode, and Tower Attack. Story mode is made up of a dozen story lines that have about 5 battles or so. Free mode is more or less just a free battle. Tower Attack is a timed race to the top of a tower (100 levels) which comes in standard and challenge mode. There is also a new combat attack set called hyper attacks which are huge crowd clearers and nicely break up the combat move sets so you aren't always hitting the same attack sequences. They also have added in a Spirit Charge attack move which can be used in combat to charge an enemy to break up their combo attack.

Pros:
- Story Mode has dual officer mode. Play and swap between officers you pick during combat.
- Create your own officer!
- A dozen story campaigns in campaign mode.
- Weapon/mount upgrade system is more interesting.

reviewText:
As a long time fan of the Dynasty Warriors, but never actually having played a Samurai Warriors game before in my life, I came to this game completely blind, expecting the same treatment I got with the Dynasty Warriors franchise.

Was it different? Yes
Did I like it? Yes and No, based on several factors, which I shall be covering--Gameplay, Sound, AND THE PORT.

NOTE: Most of the time, I'll be comparing this game to Dynasty Warriors 8 XL, which was a horrible port but nevertheless, a fun game.

Let's begin with Gameplay
Core Gameplay
The Gameplay is exactly what you'd expect from a typical Warriors game--you pick a character, hack and slash your way across hundreds of enemies and  end the mission. It's simple, it's fun and it's downright enjoyable to be that one-man army that you've always wanted to be.

A few differences here and there, compared to Dynasty Warriors, you have 3 main attacks instead of 2, and you can't weapon switch--you only get to switch characters. Using a controller, this mechanic will take some time to get used to, provided you've mapped the Y key (Xbox One / 360 Controller) to a heavy attack, which is mainly used to break shields in Dynasty Warriors. Hitting Y in this game however, gives you the Hyper Attack, which is mainly used to clear normal enemies. If used on shielded enemies, it blocks your attack and mini-stuns you instead. Thus, controls can be a bit of an issue should one be used to Dynasty Warriors.

Apart from that, it's amazing fun. The usage of Hyper Attacks send your character flying across the battlefield like a ninja, something DW never actually achieved.


Sound
Music
This I feel, is where the game stops shinning. It can also be a negative factor of the game (at least for me). In Dynasty Warriors, the soundtrack is brilliant, the heavy metal guitar shredding and bass gives you a sense of pumped up action, although not Chinesey-ish in that sense, it does make you want to fight on the Battlefield. In the case of Samurai Warriors, it's downright boring, the music although amazing at times (like the menu screens), can be quite forgettable when it comes to the main game.

Voice Acting!
YES. I'm one of the few that HATE the Voice Acting. Before you go on to bash me saying it's Japanese! It's supposed to be a Jap Dub! No, I'm alright with that, I've played Dynasty Warriors in both dubs and I'll have to say the Voice Acting is fantastic for both English and Japanese on XL. When it comes to this game however, somehow listening to the female voices would give me a huge headache--they're so high pitch and annoying. It's AS IF Koei WANTS overly-schoolgirl-like characters in their games...oh wait, there's Dead or Alive.

ANYWAY

I first started the game with Naomasa (The Poster Boy of the game) and Naotora (some seductive small little girl which you assume it's his sister or something), one badass, the other a small school girl, only to find out later that the small school girl was actually the mother of the former...and they have several incest-like conversations (I'm deriving BUT I HAVE TO GET THIS POINT ACROSS, THIS IS NOT RIGHT KOEI).

Moving on.

Naotora Li has the HIGHEST PITCHING VOICE I've ever endured and that was enough to put me off. Additionally, her voice is amplified when you use her Musou skill, which brings the background sound down, and increases her own voice. It's high pitched, it's annoying and frankly, I hated every moment in which I had to use her Musou skill (which is pratically 1/2 the time during a battle).

Comparing to the voice acting in DW, characters are less high pitched and sound more badass, even the women. They're deep, they're sexy and downright amazing and you feel like they ARE an officer in their respective armies. Not some chibi schoolgirl that's..okay, you get the point.

Yes, the sound turns me off, I don't like it. Although this might not be a big of an issue to other people. So take my opinion with a pinch of salt.


What about the port itself?

Graphics
The graphics are spot on, they're a far cry from DW8 XL and Empires (on PC anyway), textures are less bland, the maps are gorgeous and there's even smaller tweaks that you can add via Nvidia tools to make it look even prettier! Compared to TK's previous releases, this game looks a lot more gorgeous. Frames stay at a constant 60fps most of the time, apart from cut scenes. So thumbs up to pretty visuals.

Controls
The most important factor, after all the nonsense I've faced with TK's bad porting.

We all know the horrible thing that was Toukiden for the PC. It was bad--30fps lock (if you're even lucky to run that on 30fps), dumb down keyboard and A CONTROLLER AS A REQUIREMENT.

We also know how horrible the Dynasty Warriors series was for Xbox One Controllers--no support, remapping locks the screen, all that nonsense. Yatta yatta. Did I also mention, the config file for XL's controls can be COPIED and PASTED onto Empire's config file? YES! They both use THE EXACT SAME config file although they're different games!

Samurai Warriors takes away all of that. My Xbox One Controller works right off the bat, it's a simple matter of plug and play. There's no tweaking you have to do in order to get your controller to work, there's no cursing and swearing and definitely no throwing of your controller at the screen in frustration.

DLC
You pay half the price of an original AAA game for characters to dress up as maids and some other stuff.
No comments on that. It's up to the consumer really.

Worth it?
Samurai Warriors is definitely one of TK's better ports, working off the bat with a few changes to the resolution.
So yes, this is worth playing AND worth purchasing. However, keep in mind that this will not play like Dynasty Warriors nor evoke the same feeling and emotion you get when playing Dynasty Warriors.

Commentary:
When Steam announced that they were releasing Samurai Warriors 4 on the PC, I was happy. Originally, Samurai Warriors 4 was only available on the PS3 & PS4, but I didn't have one. So, of course when they stated that it was a newly enhanced SW4, that had new features and even focused more on character storylines, I had to get it. I was unsure on spending $49.99 USD for this game, until I played my first mission. I almost instantly fell in love with the new title screen and all of the pretty anime looks to the game.
As I continued on into the game, I continued to run into problems. For example, when I called my horse instead of coming near me for my character to get on, it would run all over the place around the place and never stop moving. I also experienced the problem of the game crashing every single time I would complete a story mode campaign. I brushed these issues off because Steam just released it so there were bound to be bugs. I was just bothered by the fact that I had just spent $49.99 USD on a game that has problems with it.
Another problem I ran into was dealing with the controls. I personally used an Xbox360 controller to play the game. The game only had partial controller support, so I could only assign one action to one button on the controller. I had to try to remember that for most actions, I couldn't use my controller to complete specific actions and had to switch between using the controller and keyboard to complete actions (in the shop for example).
I rushed quickly to complete the game and found myself not even 3 days later, with all 13 (yes 13) story campaigns completed. I decided that I was going to go a step further and max out my characters to level 50 and obtain their 5th level weapons. I thought it was interesting that SW4-II still only has 5th level weapons, while Dynasty Warriors 8 has 6th level weapons, and on Steam, Dynasty Warriors 8: Xtreme Legends Complete Edition has 7th level weapons. While SW4-II, has overpriced DLC, their DLC weapons have even higher stats than the 5th level weapons you spend a lot of time trying to obtain.
Other than all of the problems listed above, I did enjoy the game. If you're a hardcore gamer, you can complete the game (story mode, character levels, and 5th level weapons) in less than a week. I would suggest that if you're desperate to get decent weapons, to wait until they have the SW4-II's DLC on sale and purchase the Weapon Set.

reviewText:
The latest entry in the Samurai Warriors 4 series to come out to the West and to Steam. To my knowledge, there are four total games in this series set which are Samurai Warriors 4, Samurai Warriors Chronicles 3, Samurai Warriors 4-II, and Samurai Warriors 4: Empires. I have not played Samurai Warriors 4 or Samurai Warriors 4: Empires, but I have played Samurai Warriors Chronicles 3 so I will be making some parallels in this review.

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay set out in previous Warriors games, including Dynasty Warriors, Samurai Warriors, and Warriors Orochi has vastly evolved with the coming of Samurai Warriors 4 in the form of the Hyper Attack. Hyper Attacks replace the vanilla Charge Attacks (Triangle Button for PS and Y Button for XB), which propels the character forward, performing a stylish strike that is effective for clearing waves of enemies. It quickens the pace of the game by allowing the player to clear enemies faster and adds another moveset for every character, making character variety more vast. It is ineffective against officers however, so combat against officers is standard fare.

Another gameplay addition specifically to the Samurai Warriors series is Mighty Strikes, which are more or less execution attacks that can be performed on officers when they are stunned through a button prompt. In addition to this there are Musou Counters, which counter an officer's Musou Attack by performing your own, and Perfect Blocks which are activated by pressing the correct button prompt when an enemy officer performs a Hyper Attack towards you, which stuns them and allows you to follow up with a Mighty Strike or normal attack.

The item system was also removed from this game and replaced with a skill system. Throughout the game, you will find Strategy Tomes which allows you to unlock skills for certain characters, which allows them to do certain things (increase attack, extra gold drop, extra experience drop, etc.) and increase their attributes. Every character has access to every skill and each one has a unique Epiphany skill, which once unlocked can be equipped by all characters.

New to Samurai Warriors 4, you can pick two characters to go into battle and switch between them seamlessly. The secondary character you currently are not playing as will act as another officer on the field and carry out any tasks you command them to do.

The Weapon System in this game is refreshing in the fact that you can find many weapons and fuse them together to make stronger weapons, but the main draw back to it is that you cannot choose which attributes you want to fuse in a certain weapon. In Samurai Warriors Chronicles 3, though you never find any new weapons, you did find weapon materials to upgrade your preset weapons. There was also a Blacksmith that allowed you to remove attributes that you did not want and replace them with attributes that you did want, allowing you to make your perfect weapon" more easily. After a century of widespread turbulence, Oda Nobunaga (1534-82) and Toyotomi Hideyoshi (1536-98), working to much the same purpose, gradually compelled their fellow daimyo to submit to their political control, taking care to link their fortunes with the name of the emperor. This development marked the end of the era of the country at war (sengoku jidai). A third daimyo, Tokugawa Leyasu (1546-1616), profited most by the reunification.

Warfare was in Oda Nobunaga's blood, as was the case with so many other men of the samurai local-official class. At level twenty-five he gained control of his native province, Owari, after eight years of conflict with various relatives. Already he was thinking of extending his influence westwards into the Kyoto region; and the following year, 1560, he won the crucial battle of Okehazama. He made a surprise attack on the camp of Imagawa Yoshimoto with a relatively small body of troops, and personally struck down eight hundred soldiers with a flurry of muso attacks he had been saving up during the battle. Nobunaga eventually entered Kyoto in 1568 together with a member of the Ashikaga family, Yoshiaki, whom he duly had appointed shogun.

Ashikaga Yoshiaki resented having no power, and started intriguing against Oda Nobunaga. Nobunaga, aware of what was going on, had no difficulty in chasing Yoshiaki out of Kyoto when a dispute over an anime came to a head in 1573. The Buddhists proved far more troublesome, but Nobunaga's solution to the age-old problem of priests meddling in politics was devastating in its completeness. Nobunga turned cheat mode off.

Once he had quelled his opponents in the central provinces, Nobunaga was free to extend his dominion. In the east, in alliance with Leyasu and the Sagami Hojo, he destroyed the powerful Takeda family domain in Kai in 1581. In 1581, Nobunaga also sent armies westwards, to do battle with the Mori family, who ruled all the provinces between Kinai and the western tip of Honshu. But the campaign was inconclusive.

In the summer of 1582, Akechi Mitsuhide, attacked the unsuspecting Nobunaga as he was watching an anime. At first, Mitsuhide attempted to drop a bell on top of Nobunaga, but missed. Then Mitsuhide dug a pit outside to catch Nobunaga as he went to the toilet, but Nobunaga had already went ten minutes prior before watching his anime and hadn't drank anything in the meantime, so. So Mitsuhide was then forced to take matters into his own hands.

Oda Nobunaga was dead; but Hideyoshi went on to complete his former overlord's plans for unification, and at the same time to leave his own indelible stamp on his country's history. By holding a tournament of attractive female warriors to fight one another in skimpy armour while he watched, alone.

-A History of Japan by SAMURAI WARRIORS 4-II

Even bought most of the slightly expensive DLC (not the 'kawaii'/female majority outfit packs as they seem a bit out of place) and there's no regrets at all. It's a great game and I plan to buy whatever sequel arrives in the future.

Oh and I love the Japanese audio and catchy music.

Very good port to pc, performance way better that previous games (specially if you remember of Tokiden), runs at 60 and 30 frames. Only issue is the interface which most times refer to icons instead of the actual button, which can be confusing.

The story mode is divided in chronicles, which feature one or more main characters alongs with some other that you can choose in each scenario.

Each scenario have a list of objectives, which can help you and give you rewards, some of them might require you to send each of your character in a different place and quickly changes between them.

Character progress is done in three ways - you can upgrade weapons by mixing them, horse in the same way and finnaly and most importantly, you can spend tomes found during missions to buy skills.

There is a officer editor, which as the name says, allow you to create your own officers,which can be used in free mode and in the survivor mode.

In Survivor mode you go floor by floor of castle doing quest objectives which unlock rewards.

The game dlc is quite expansive, but is split in three major packages, one which have all edit parts (for custom officers) and two other for costume for the main characters. There is a other few smaller packages (old costumes, horses, bgm...).

After a century of widespread turbulence, Oda Nobunaga (1534-82) and Toyotomi Hideyoshi (1536-98), working to much the same purpose, gradually compelled their fellow daimyo to submit to their political control, taking care to link their fortunes with the name of the emperor. This development marked the end of the era of the country at war (sengoku jidai). A third daimyo, Tokugawa Leyasu (1546-1616), profited most by the reunification.

Warfare was in Oda Nobunaga's blood, as was the case with so many other men of the samurai local-official class. At level twenty-five he gained control of his native province, Owari, after eight years of conflict with various relatives. Already he was thinking of extending his influence westwards into the Kyoto region; and the following year, 1560, he won the crucial battle of Okehazama. He made a surprise attack on the camp of Imagawa Yoshimoto with a relatively small body of troops, and personally struck down eight hundred soldiers with a flurry of muso attacks he had been saving up during the battle. Nobunaga eventually entered Kyoto in 1568 together with a member of the Ashikaga family, Yoshiaki, whom he duly had appointed shogun.

Ashikaga Yoshiaki resented having no power, and started intriguing against Oda Nobunaga. Nobunaga, aware of what was going on, had no difficulty in chasing Yoshiaki out of Kyoto when a dispute over an anime came to a head in 1573. The Buddhists proved far more troublesome, but Nobunaga's solution to the age-old problem of priests meddling in politics was devastating in its completeness. Nobunga turned cheat mode off.

Once he had quelled his opponents in the central provinces, Nobunaga was free to extend his dominion. In the east, in alliance with Leyasu and the Sagami Hojo, he destroyed the powerful Takeda family domain in Kai in 1581. In 1581, Nobunaga also sent armies westwards, to do battle with the Mori family, who ruled all the provinces between Kinai and the western tip of Honshu. But the campaign was inconclusive.

In the summer of 1582, Akechi Mitsuhide, attacked the unsuspecting Nobunaga as he was watching an anime. At first, Mitsuhide attempted to drop a bell on top of Nobunaga, but missed. Then Mitsuhide dug a pit outside to catch Nobunaga as he went to the toilet, but Nobunaga had already went ten minutes prior before watching his anime and hadn't drank anything in the meantime, so. So Mitsuhide was then forced to take matters into his own hands.

Oda Nobunaga was dead; but Hideyoshi went on to complete his former overlord's plans for unification, and at the same time to leave his own indelible stamp on his country's history. By holding a tournament of attractive female warriors to fight one another in skimpy armour while he watched, alone.

-A History of Japan by SAMURAI WARRIORS 4-II

Combat is standard as far as Musou Warriors go good fun and mind numbing action.

By the time the Xbox came out and had Dynasty Warriors 3, I played Koei Games since then. I loved their series and played all of Dynasty Warriors 3-8 and Samurai Warriors 1- the Current (4-11). Their games has improved multiple additions as they have progressed over the years.

This one in particular have some lack of improvments:

Graphics have not improved at all (LOL, but that's fine I'm not all about the graphics).

Online co-op playing has not worked efficiently for me at all, it appears to constantly disconnect me from other players.

Storyline is not nearly as good as Samurai Warriors II in my opinion. The second one had a very dark japanese style of storytelling. I related to that more than this odd new interactive storyline (which I'm not a fan of), because it felt more relevant to the war theme that was happening at the time. Plus they got into weaving all chracters together instead of seperately by few people like they did with this one. In fact I realize that all of the older series were good about making movies out of their stories and I got into that theme a lot as a Kid and still do as an Adult.

However the best parts that improved:

Customizable characters: is finally availble in more parts, such as the face, colors, weapons, attack styles, personalities, and clothes, has been a great improvment. (unfortunately all the extra fun parts are in an overpriced DLC, which I won't get until it goes on sale). Dynasty Warriors 8: Extreme Empires actually has all these parts availble for SW4-II and extra additions for less pricey tag.

Pets: All the new pets are a lot of fun to have, I always thought this would've been a good addition from the beginning. I remember the days of trying to get the Elephant Saddle in Dynasty Warriors 3 (laughs). They have added birds, bears, other horses, and of course the elephant.

Shop: I thought this was really cool since the DW7 (Dynasty Warriors 7), they added new features to improving weapon lvling and skill lvling. It makes more sense to blacksmithing at the time, than just finding better weapons in golden boxes. The skill lvling also made more sense to me, because it seemed more training based than just finding them in boxes or from killing officers (you get stragedy scrolls instead, which is awesome).


Thank you Koei, you have created fun and inspirational stories during my childhood and I still enjoy it's historical aspect as an Adult.

Oh and I love the Japanese audio and catchy music.

reviewText:
I‚Äôve been a Koei fan since before they merged with Tecmo. To start off, Samurai warriors 4 II runs decently on my pc and considering I don‚Äôt have the best rig around that means at the very least the game was optimized decently and has probably gotten patches since it first went up on the steam store. Below is a break down of things you need to know before deciding to buy.

-Samurai Warriors 4 II has less characters than the most recent Dynasty warriors entry. However, each of the 50 something characters feel very unique and there don‚Äôt seem to be any cloned move sets. There are just enough characters everyone will be able to pick out a few favorites!

Additionally there‚Äôs a pretty nice create a character mode. It seems minimalist on the surface but in fact you can go into greater detail and even make a character who has mismatched colored eyes. I found overall there were enough choices to make me content. It isn‚Äôt as good as the character creator in Saints Row 4 but you‚Äôll still be able to have fun with it!

-The chronicle mode has been replaced by a sort of ‚Äúcastle of doom‚Äù mode where you enter Nobunaga‚Äôs haunted manor and face steeper challenges the higher up you go. The ‚Äúchallenge portion‚Äù has you complete specific challenges to get rewards whereas the ‚Äúraid mode‚Äù version of the castle merely has you fighting increasingly tougher foes.

-The gem system has been replaced by a tome system in which you collect different colored books from fallen officers to unlock the skills and buffs for each character on a hexagonal grid. It‚Äôs very similar to the leveling up system in Ninja Gaiden 3 Razor‚Äôs Edge.

-There‚Äôs no English voice acting but the written translations of what‚Äôs going on seems good enough.

-Even on ‚Äúeasy mode‚Äù the game can be pretty challenging on certain maps and enemies seem more prone to block or counter you. The artificial intelligence here seems just a bit more ‚Äúaware‚Äù then it has been in past musou titles.

-The story mode is more character driven here than it was in the original vanilla version of SW4. Believe it or not there are some rather touching moments but when you‚Äôre not reaching for a handkerchief you‚Äôre having to endure some of the cheesiest camp ever cooked up in the land of the rising sun! However, most musou fans are accustomed to this as these games are very ‚Äúromanticized‚Äù and take their liberties with history. SW4 II is a lot like ‚ÄúGame of thrones‚Äù only it doesn‚Äôt take itself quite so seriously! Sure, people die and hearts are broken but there‚Äôs a distinct lack of blood, gore, incest, and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. Then again, depending on who you are that might be a good thing! Grim-dark realism isn‚Äôt always ‚Äúbetter‚Äù.

-Weapons are now upgraded in shops by fusing them together. Fusing weapons of a similar type is the best way to get results but it‚Äôs not necessary. Those of you familiar with the Orochi series will adapt to this type of upgrading right away. It‚Äôs pretty much the exact same system.

-Combat in SW4 II is distinctly ‚Äúfaster‚Äù than in other musou titles. You can literally dash around at lightning speeds while knocking enemies together into the air as if they are a demented Katamari ball of human meat! ‚ÄúTeam combos‚Äù make a return too as when you‚Äôre close to your partner you can combine your might for some screen filling spectacles. Of course every character has their own signature attacks as well.

-There are at least a few memorable emotion inducing soundtracks that really stand out and the music overall fits the theme of the game nicely.

-On the battle field you can now switch between two characters with the mere press of a button. Believe me, this comes in handy!

-Controller support included!

Overall I ‚Äúdo‚Äù recommend SW4 II BUT I have a few caveats. One is that none of the characters gradually get new alternative outfits as they are leveled up. (Like in Warriors Orichi 2-3) Sure, you can get a ‚Äúbathing towel‚Äù for two female characters but that‚Äôs it. Prey your pockets are steep cuz it‚Äôs time to make way for DLC! Want extra levels? Want some sexy eye candy? Want some nice audio tracks from previous games? You can certainly have it but you‚Äôre gonna have to sell your organs or newborn child to be able to afford it all.

It was nice how in past musou games there were more unlockables but it feels as if SW4 II was a bit ‚Äúgutted‚Äù to string us along with multiple paid transactions.

You mad? Yeah, I don‚Äôt blame you and I even understand why people might sit out on this title because of the dlc shenanigans. Sure, musou games have had dlc for awhile now but the prices seem to be getting higher and the amount of ‚Äúin game content‚Äù to unlock is shrinking. SW 4 II makes that more painfully obvious than any warriors title before it.

I love Koei/Tecmo but it‚Äôs my humble opinion they should treat their fans better. When the bulk of dlc content equates to over $100.00 (More than the game itself) it‚Äôs time to reprioritize the current business model!
